September 18, 1929.
To the Hon. Milo H. Kent
Chairman of the Airport Comnittee,
Board of Supervisors,
City of San Francisco,
California,
Sir:
Inasmuch as the Chairman of the advisory Committee on
Aviation to the City of San Francisco, is leaving on a trip,
Burope, which will consure at least two months time, a meeting of
the Advisory Committee was held on this date, in order that this
report could be furnished to you of the unanimous sentiment, feel-
ings and recormendations of the Advisory Comittee.
In oase you, or the Board of Supervisors, find it
necessary to possess any further details regarding the attitude
of this Committee, during my absence, you on cal 1 upon Lieutenant-
Colonel Gerald C.
the Comittee,
Brant, or B. B. Mouton, the other members of
for such Information.
There is no divergence of
opinion among the members of this Comittee,
recommendations they may make
and any statement or
can be considered as having my
heartiest endorsement and approval.
On larch 26th last, Ir. Marshall Fale, President of the
Down Town Association, stated that he had recommended me, as Chair-
man of the Aviation Committee of the Down Town Association, to be
a member of the Advisory Committee on Aviation, to be appointed by
the Mayor.
On
April 8th last, I read in the newspapers that such
a committee had been appointed, consisting of Lieutenant-Colonel
Gerald C. Brant and 3.
B. Mouton and myself but that you had ex-
pressed some uncertainty as to the possibility of securing Colonel
Brant, or Ir. Mouton, because of their federal connections.
I
called you on the telephone several times between that date and
the date of the first meeting of our Committee, on May 3, 1929.
and was informed by you that the personnel of the Comittee had
not yet been definitely determined, because of Wer Department objet-
ions to the service of Colonel Brant on the Cormittee.
When our Advisory Committee finally did meet with your
Airport Comittee in joint conference, on May 3, 1929, at the Palace
Hotel, the entire situation was informally discussed.
The members
of our Committee were in agreement with the facts presented by you
that Mills Fleld, 1f properly developed, would make a satisfactory
aviation base (as distinguished from aviation terminal).
